lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
DUKE is a task manager program that is made for use via a Command Line Interface (CLI)
What can I do for you?
* Mark a task item as completed: `done`
2. Open a terminal and execute `java -jar ip.jar` in the directory `ip.jar` is in.
* Code in `UPPER_CASE` represent input fields that must be supplied by users for commands to work
Add a `todo` type task into the task list.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list
Add an `event` type task into the task list.
* `at :` is used only if the user wants to store `OCCURING_AT` in a `MMM-DD-YYYY` format
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 2 task in the list
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 3 task in the list
Add a `deadline` type task into the task list.
* `by: ` is used only if the user wants to store `DUE_BY` in a `MMM-DD-YYYY` format
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 4 task in the list
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 5 task in the list
Show a list of all the task recorded.
Here are the tasks in your list:
Show a list of all tasks that matches a specific keyword or phrase in the `DESCRIPTION` field.
* `KEYWORD` can be either a word or, a phrase
Here are the tasks in your list:
Removes a task from the list
* `TASK_INDEX` is the number corresponding to the task on the list. The number must be a positive integer.
Now you have 2 task in the list.
### Mark a task item as completed: `done`
Use for marking a task as completed.
* `TASK_INDEX` is the number corresponding to the task on the list. The number must be a positive integer.
* Each task can only be marked done once. Once a task is marked `done` it cannot be undone.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Here are the tasks in your list:
* All the data in the task list will be saved in file in the same directory as the program for future access.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
Add event | `event DESCPRIPTION /[at:] OCCURING_AT` eg.`event CS2113 consultation /at: 2021-10-01`
Add deadline | `deadline DESCPRIPTION /[by:] DUE_BY` eg. `deadline CS2113 tp /by: 2021-10-01`
* This is a application that simulates a todo list. It is able to read, write and delete items,
* as well as mark items in the list as completed.
* Represent the startup of the application. The user interface and storage used to store file data
* is instantiated here. If the file that is used to store data cannot be read, the program will show
* an error message and will terminate with exit code -1
* @param filePath relative path where the file used to store the data of the task list is located at
* Responsible for listening for input from user and execute commands depending on the input string
* from the users. If there is any error while attempting to parse the input string or while executing
* the command, a message associated with the error will be printed and another input will be prompted
* Create an instance of the application and run the application. The application will only terminate
* if the terminate command is executed or if there is an error loading the file
* @param args the variable argument field is not used in this program
* This class is used to parse string inputs from users and return the input commands as objects
* that can be executed, according to the commands specified by the user
* Returns an executable command object based on the input string where the command type and other additional
* information is specified. If the command cannot be parsed appropriately or if the command the user has
* input is incorrect, an exception will be thrown
* @param request It is the string input users enter in the command line to interact with the application
* @return The method returns a command object which contains a method to carry out the specified command on the task list
* @throws Exception it is thrown when an error occur when attempting to parse the input command
public static Command parse(String request) throws Exception {

* handling the manipulation of the task list like adding, deleting and viewing the tasks.

* Returns the number of tasks in the task list

* @return tasks as an ArrayList so it can be written to the file storing file data
* Check if the task list does not contain any task
* @return true if the task list is empty else it returns false
* Returns the task at the specified index that is in the task list. If the index is too large,
* an exception will be thrown, telling the user that the task at the index does not exist
* @param index Index of the task in the task list that the user wants to retrieve
* @return A task if the index exist in the task list else an exception will be returned
throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException(" OOPS!!! The list does not have that many task ><");

* This class is used to add task into the task list

* This class is the parent class to all the different command classes, based on the capabilities of
* Specifies the type of command by storing the type of command as a string
* @param command It is a string that represents that command type
* Based on the type of command, different command classes will require the task list, ui and storage
* @param tasks the task list that stores task for the application which is manipulated based on the command
* @param ui the user interface that interacts with users which prints messages based on the different commands
* @param storage the area which data can be read from and written to, to save task list data permanently
* @throws IOException is thrown when storage fail to store task list data in the files
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws IOException;

* This class is thrown when the task information fields like time and description are missing. It
* stores the message specific to the task type and the fields that are lacking
* Creates a exception class that stores the task type it is related to
* @param taskType it is the name of the task that cause this exception
* Depending on the task type, the error message that the exception will show is different.
* For todo task, the error would be an empty description field while for events and deadlines
* the error would be empty descriptions or timing fields
* @return a string of the error message that corresponds to the task
return String.format(" OOPS!!! The check that the description of %s is not empty", taskType);
return String.format(" OOPS!!! The check that the description and time fields of %s is not empty", taskType);
* This class is thrown when the filter word field is missing from the find command. It

return "Input a filter you want to search by";
* This class is thrown when the input command does not match any available command. It
* stores the message that tells the user that no command is executed.
* Returns a message that tells user the command is invalid
* @return a string storing the error message
return String.format(" OOPS!!! I can't do that.");
